text: In the last month, I started working on a problem before anyone asked me to.
When I see something broken on my team, I fix it or flag it within the hour — I don't wait for someone else to notice.
I often feel like things aren't moving fast enough, even when my team says we're on track.
I set goals for myself that most people around me would consider unrealistic.
In the last month, I pitched an idea or project that didn't exist on anyone's roadmap.
I'm comfortable making a decision with 70% of the information rather than waiting for 100%.
After finishing a big project, I prefer to take it easy for a while before jumping into the next thing.
I tend to wait until priorities are clearly assigned before I start working on something new.
I'd rather hold something back until it's polished than ship a rough version and iterate.
When a goal starts to feel out of reach, I push harder instead of resetting expectations.
I'm usually fine with the pace my organization moves at — I don't feel the need to push things faster.
In the last month, I volunteered to lead something that wasn't part of my job description.
I regularly feel frustrated by how long it takes to get approvals or buy-in.
I prefer to stay in my current role and master it rather than constantly chase the next promotion.
When I commit to a deadline, I treat it like a promise — I'll rearrange my week to make it happen.
I find it hard to relax on weekends because I keep thinking about what I could be getting done.
When there's no clear process for something, I'll build one myself rather than wait for guidance.
I don't usually think about where I'll be in five years — I focus on what's in front of me.
I actively seek out responsibilities that will stretch me beyond my current skill set.
When the workday ends, I have no trouble switching off — work stays at work.
In the last month, I took on a task that others had given up on because I believed I could make it work.
I have never procrastinated on an important task.
I generally don't volunteer for extra work unless it's clearly tied to a reward or recognition.
When I notice a gap between what my team says we'll do and what's actually happening, I'm the one who raises it.
I'm usually the first person on my team to call out when we're falling behind on a commitment.
You've been in your role for six months and notice that a key client onboarding process has several manual steps that waste hours each week. Nobody has complained about it. What do you do?

options.text: Build a rough prototype of a better process over the weekend and pitch it to your manager on Monday.
Raise it at the next team meeting and suggest forming a working group to redesign the process.
Document the inefficiencies and send a detailed memo to leadership outlining the problem.
Focus on your own responsibilities — if it were a real problem, someone more senior would have addressed it by now.

text: Your team has a deadline in three days, but you just realized the data you need from another department won't arrive for a week. What do you do?

options.text: Go directly to the other department's lead, explain the urgency, and ask what it would take to get it sooner.
Start building what you can with placeholder data so the team doesn't lose momentum.
Notify your manager that the timeline is at risk and ask them to escalate.
Adjust the project plan to reflect the new reality and communicate the delay to stakeholders.

text: You just wrapped up a grueling quarter — your team hit every target. Your boss offers you a choice: take the next quarter easy with a maintenance project, or lead a high-visibility initiative that could fast-track your career but will be just as intense. What do you choose?

options.text: Take the high-visibility initiative — you didn't get here by coasting, and you want to keep building momentum.
Take the high-visibility initiative but negotiate for extra headcount so you can sustain the pace.
Take the maintenance project — you've earned a breather, and your team needs to recover too.
Ask for a week to think about it — you want to assess whether the initiative aligns with your long-term goals.

text: A new tool could save your team 10 hours a week, but your organization's procurement process takes months. You have the skills to build a rough version yourself in a couple of evenings. What do you do?

options.text: Build the rough version yourself this week — the time savings compound and waiting is expensive.
Submit the procurement request and build a temporary workaround to bridge the gap.
Submit the procurement request and wait — building ad hoc tools creates maintenance debt.
Rally a few teammates to build it together so the solution has broader support and knowledge.

text: You've been eyeing a director-level role that just opened up. You meet most of the requirements but are missing experience in one key area. What do you do?

options.text: Apply immediately and address the gap in your cover letter — you'll learn fast once you're in the seat.
Talk to the hiring manager first to understand how critical that gap is, then decide.
Spend the next six months building that missing experience, then apply for the next similar opening.
Ask your current manager to give you a stretch assignment in the gap area so you can apply with confidence in a few months.

text: It's Friday afternoon and your team just discovered a bug that affects a small number of users. It's not critical, and the fix is straightforward but would take about three hours. What do you do?

options.text: Stay and fix it now — three hours isn't worth the anxiety of leaving it over the weekend.
Fix it first thing Monday morning and send a quick note to affected users acknowledging the issue.
Add it to the sprint backlog and prioritize it against other items next week.
Delegate it to someone on the team who has bandwidth and is looking for something to own.

text: You've been working 60-hour weeks for the past month on a critical launch. Your partner tells you they're feeling neglected, and you notice you're making more mistakes at work. A colleague suggests you take a few days off. What do you do?

options.text: Push through — the launch is in two weeks and you can rest after. You've powered through worse.
Take one day off this week to reset, then reassess whether you can delegate some of the load.
Talk to your manager about redistributing work — you want to finish strong but recognize you're hitting a wall.
Take the few days off — you'll be more effective rested, and the team can cover for you.

text: Your company's annual planning cycle just started. You can either submit goals you're confident you'll hit (which locks in your bonus), or submit stretch goals that would impress leadership but carry real risk of missing. What do you do?

options.text: Go with the stretch goals — you'd rather aim high and miss than set a bar you know you'll clear.
Submit the safe goals publicly but privately hold yourself to the stretch targets.
Submit the safe goals — hitting targets consistently builds more career capital than occasional big swings.
Talk to your manager about what goals would signal readiness for the next level, then calibrate accordingly.

text: You're leading a team meeting and someone proposes an approach that would add two weeks to the timeline but significantly reduce risk. You believe the risk is manageable. What do you do?

options.text: Push back on the two-week delay — you can manage the risk on the fly and keeping pace matters more.
Thank them for the input, then propose a middle ground: one week extra with a lighter risk mitigation plan.
Accept the two weeks — you'd rather have the team aligned and confident than save time with people worried.
Ask the team to quantify the actual risk — you want data, not gut feelings, before you slow down.

text: You've been given a project with vague requirements and no clear owner. Your manager says 'figure it out.' What's your first move?

options.text: Define the scope yourself based on what you think makes sense, start executing, and course-correct as feedback comes in.
Schedule 30-minute calls with the three people most likely to care about the outcome and triangulate what 'good' looks like.
Go back to your manager and push for clearer requirements — you don't want to waste effort heading the wrong direction.
Spend a day researching how similar projects were handled at other companies to avoid reinventing the wheel.

text: You realize your direct report has been sitting on a deliverable for two weeks because they're stuck and haven't asked for help. The client expects it in five days. What do you do?

options.text: Jump in and co-work with them for the next two days to get it back on track — the deadline is what matters right now.
Have a candid conversation about what blocked them, then reassign part of the work to someone who can move faster.
Ask the client for a one-week extension and use it as a coaching moment for the direct report.
Escalate to your manager — this pattern of not raising flags needs to be addressed structurally, not just for this deliverable.

text: You've been heads-down on a project for months and just realized a competitor launched something nearly identical last week. Your team is demoralized. What's your response?

options.text: Accelerate the launch timeline — being second to market is fine if you move fast and differentiate on quality.
Gather the team and reframe: study the competitor's product to find gaps you can exploit, then adjust your plan.
Take a day to regroup emotionally as a team, then decide whether to pivot, accelerate, or shelve it.
Present the situation honestly to leadership and let them decide whether to continue investing in this direction.

text: Your team just missed its quarterly target by 15%. During the review, your manager asks each person what went wrong. When it's your turn, you:

options.text: Own what you could have done differently, then immediately pivot to what you're going to do to make up the gap this quarter.
Point to the two systemic blockers that you flagged early but nobody addressed — the team needs to fix the root causes.
Focus on what the team did well and reframe the miss as a learning opportunity — morale matters right now.
Present a detailed analysis of which specific initiatives underperformed and propose killing the two lowest-ROI ones.

text: A peer on another team asks you to collaborate on a cross-functional project. It's interesting but not aligned with your current goals and would require about 5 hours a week. What do you do?

options.text: Decline politely — you're laser-focused on your own targets and can't afford to dilute your effort.
Say yes if you can see how it builds a relationship or skill that accelerates your own goals.
Say yes — you thrive when you're juggling multiple high-energy projects and it keeps things fresh.
Counter-propose a lighter involvement — you'll advise but not co-own, so you can stay focused.

text: You just got feedback that your team finds your pace exhausting. People are keeping up, but several have privately said they feel like there's no room to breathe. What do you do?

options.text: Acknowledge the feedback but hold the pace — the results speak for themselves, and good people rise to the challenge.
Slow down slightly and build in recovery periods after big pushes — sustainable intensity beats burnout.
Identify the two or three highest-impact activities and go hard on those, while deliberately creating slack everywhere else.
Have one-on-ones with each person to understand their specific limits and customize the workload accordingly.

text: You're offered two roles at different companies. Role A: stable, well-compensated, clear path to VP in 3 years. Role B: early-stage startup, equity-heavy, you'd be building the team from scratch with no guarantee of success. Which do you take?

options.text: Role B without hesitation — the upside is massive and you'd get bored on a predictable path.
Role A — you can always join a startup later, but this kind of accelerated trajectory is rare.
Role B, but only after negotiating a higher base — you need to manage the downside risk.
Role A — you've seen too many people burn out chasing startup dreams. Steady compounding wins.

text: You're three months into a strategic initiative and the early data suggests it's not working. You've invested significant political capital in championing this. What do you do?

options.text: Double down — three months isn't enough data, and pivoting too early signals weakness. Push harder.
Present the data transparently to leadership with two options: a revised approach or a clean shutdown.
Quietly adjust the approach while keeping the same branding — same initiative, different tactics, no need to publicize the struggle.
Talk to the people closest to the work and get their honest read before deciding — you might be missing something.

text: When a project hits a wall, your first instinct is to:

options.text: Find another angle and keep pushing — walls are just problems you haven't solved yet.
Step back and figure out if the wall is telling you to change direction entirely.

text: Your team just missed a major deadline. Your gut response:

options.text: Figure out how to recover the lost time — you're already running scenarios in your head.
Check in with the team first — you need to understand what happened before you can fix it.

text: A colleague suggests slowing down to reassess. You feel:

options.text: Restless — slowing down usually means losing ground you can't get back.
Relieved — a pause to think clearly is almost always worth it.

text: You have one hour before a big presentation and discover a significant error in the data. You:

options.text: Fix what you can in the hour, present with caveats, and follow up with the corrected version — momentum matters.
Ask to reschedule — presenting flawed data damages your credibility more than a delay would.

text: When you look at your career over the next decade, what matters more to you:

options.text: How far you've climbed — title, scope, impact, and the stretch it took to get there.
How deep your relationships are — the people you've built things with and the trust you've earned.

text: It's Sunday evening and you just had an idea that could solve a problem at work. You:

options.text: Open your laptop and start sketching it out — the energy is there and you don't want to lose it.
Jot a note for Monday — you protect your off-hours because that's what keeps you sharp during the week.

text: Your manager gives you a goal you think is too easy. Your move:

options.text: Propose a harder target — hitting easy goals doesn't excite you and doesn't grow you.
Hit the easy goal fast, then use the remaining time to explore something new on your own terms.

text: You're choosing between two vacation styles. Which sounds more like you:

options.text: Packed itinerary — new city every two days, maximum experiences, sleep on the plane home.
One place, no plans — you recharge by fully disconnecting and letting things happen.

text: Two people you respect give you opposite advice: one says 'go faster,' the other says 'go deeper.' You lean toward:

options.text: Go faster — speed creates options, and you can always course-correct.
Go deeper — getting it right once beats doing it over three times.

text: You find out a peer who started the same role as you just got promoted. Your honest reaction:

options.text: A fire lights under you — you start thinking about what you need to do to be next.
You're genuinely happy for them — your path is your path and comparison doesn't serve you.
